On 17 March 2020, about 20 residents of apartment building 16 on Nukus street in Tashkent city protested against the residential apartment complex project in their backyard demanding the Uzbek authorities probe the project for its legality. [size=about 20]

On 15 March 2020, 30-40 garage owners gathered in Karasu-4 neighborhood of Mirzo Ulugbek district in Tashkent city to protest against demolition of 400 garages including theirs by a private developer. [size=30-40]

Around 14 March 2020, property owners organized a demonstration against the demolition of incomplete home property in the village of Tukbay near Qamashi township in Kashkadarya region. Rioters blocked access to demolition equipment which triggered a brawl between them and policemen. [size=no report]

On 11 March 2020, 20-30 small shop owners, led by the women shop owners, protested at the central market in the town of Pop in Namangan region demanding the local administration give their spots back at the market. Protesters appealed to the Uzbek president for help with their dispute complaining they have lost their livelihoods due to the renovation of the local market which was initiated by the district authorities. [size=20-30]

On 11 March 2020, more than 10 residents of the local neighborhood in Yunusabad district of Tashkent city protested against takeover of their local park by the bank to build an office at the location. Protesters demanded their small park preserved the way it is and no construction activity at the park in the future. [size=more than 10]

On 11 March 2020, about 10 residents of Kiyot neighborhood in Yunusabad district of Tashkent city protested against takeover of their backyard and playground for children by the private company which was planning to build commercial project at the location. Protesters demanded the company remove fencing from their backyard and the authorities intervene in the dispute. [size=about 10]

On 11 March 2020, 10-20 residents of the Feruza neighborhood in Mirzo-Ulugbek district protested against a private developer company's seizure on a piece of land belonging to the neighborhood. Protesters demanded the city prosecutor's office take immediate action to return the land back to residents. [size=10-20]

On 9 March 2020, dozens of cotton processing plant workers protested on the plant premises in Dustlik village of Dostik district in Dzhizak region against delay with pay and decreasing wages. Protesters demanded the management pay their salaries on time. [size=dozens]

On 8 March 2020, 5 residents of Boikurgon neighborhood in Yashnobod district of Tashkent city protested against construction of multi floor apartment building on their street demanding the local authorities check legality of developer's plan. [size=5]

On 6 March 2020, more than 20 residents living near the Transport Institute in Mirabad district of Tashkent city protested against takeover of their residential backyard and children's playground by the district administration and developer to build a commercial real estate. A number of local city officials, Uzbek lawmakers, journalists and activists supported the event. [size=more than 20]

On 4 March 2020, about 60 protesters from across Uzbekistan, demonstrated outside the presidential administration in Tashkent city demanding a meeting with head of the administration's department on human rights to address their complaints and concerns regarding the violation of their rights. 15 men protesters then were detained by the police and taken away to the nearby station. [size=about 60]

On 4 March 2020, 5-10 residents of the apartment building on Mirzo Ulugbek avenue in Tashkent city protested against a planned construction of the automobile service shop and shopping plaza in their backyard. Protesters demanded a green park and sports ground for their kids instead. [size=5-10]

On 26 February 2020, about 12 residents of Mirabad district in Tashkent city protested near Nukus and Oybek streets against the new housing development demanding a green park instead. Protesters complained their children will not have a playground with trees around if the housing development goes forward. [size=about 12]

On 26 February 2020, owners of demolished homes protested at the construction site in Fergana city, demanding compensation for their properties, which protesters complained they haven't received since 2018. [size=no report]

On 24 February 2020, 30-40 victims of the private company Straus House fraudulent activity, which has inflicted financial damages on them in the amount of 7.4 billion Uzbek sum, gathered near Independence square in Tashkent city in protest of protracted court trial requesting the Uzbek government's assistance with speeding up the court process, demanding exact date and clarity on how long it will take for a court trial to go on. [size=30-40]

On 18 February 2020, about 3 rioters, who own a local liquor and grocery store, attacked an Uzbek blogger near the Holid Ibn Walid mosque in Asaka town of Andizhan region of Uzbekistan after blogger criticized them online over selling alcohol near the mosque. [size=about 3]

On 17 February 2020, more than 100 victims of the employment fraud from across Uzbekistan gathered near Mustakillik square close to the country's cabinet office in Tashkent city, demanding compensation from the responsible job agency. As the protest continued, high ranking Uzbek officials met with the protesters including Prime-Minister who ordered his government to compensate 1086 victims of the scheme. [size=more than 100]

On 14 February 2020, about 30 rioters of the Halqabod neighborhood in Altinsay district of Surkhandarya region of Uzbekistan rioted against the planned demolition of their homes by the district authorities. Uzbek police was called in to disperse the crowd who clashed with policemen using sticks, bolts, shovels and stones. At least several villagers and two or more policemen wounded. [size=about 30]

On 23 January 2020, about 100 Uzbek farmers protested at the district administration's office and local Agrobank in Sardoba town of Akaltyn district in Sirdaryo region of Uzbekistan demanding their payments for cotton they sold to the local authorities in 2019. [size=about 100]

On 17 January 2020, about 20 former employees of the Uzbekistan's Sanitary-Epidemiological Agency's branch in the town of Chiroqchi gathered at the agency branch to protest against mass lay-off which left 150 people jobless. Protesters demanded the agency provide them with jobs. [size=about 20]
On 16 January 2020, retail shop owners protested at the bazaar in Chilanzar section of Tashkent city against planned renovation at the market demanding their shops remain untouched. [size=no report]

On 13 January 2020, about 30 drivers, who make a living by driving customers and delivering goods between Russia and Uzbekistan, gathered outside the Uzbek parliament in Chilanzar district of Tashkent city in protest of the newly adopted customs fees and rates for improting goods from abroad. [size=about 30]

On 11 January 2020, dozens of protesters demanded a local police officer be punished for drunk driving after getting caught on the road by local residents in Chiroqchi town of Chiroqchi district in Kashkadarya region of Uzbekistan. [size=dozens]

On 11 January 2020, about 100 homeowners gathered outside the regional administration office in Navoi city in protest of demolition of their properties. Spokesman for the administration told protesters the issue is under review which may take several months. [size=about 100]
On 10 January, more than 3 workers of a cotton processing plant in Pskent district of Tashkent region protested against the mistreatment demanding owed pay for 3 months. [size=more than 3]

On 3 January, more than 5 local small business owners in Pastdargom district of Samarkand region gathered outside the regional gas supply office in Samarkand city demanding gas supply. Protesters said they are facing possible bankruptcy if gas supply is not sustained. [size=more than 5]

On 9 December, about 7 female protesters blocked the Shavat-Urganch road for few hours by the Shavat district administration in protest against the ongoing crisis of supply of natural gas in Uzbekistan. Police were called to the scene after which the women unblocked the road. [size=about 7]

On 3 December, about 20 villagers of Oqbuyra town in Fergana region protested against the late-night inspection of their household gas supply sources by the local authorities. The inspection team was forced to leave the area after the resentment. [size=about 20]
On 1 December, an unknown number of Barkamol neighborhood residents protested due to short supply of natural gas in Fegrana city. [size=unknown]

On 1 December, about 20 residents of Bustan in Ellikqala district of Karakalpakstan region of Uzbekistan blocked the road after their households were cut short of natural gas supply. Local administration chief told the newspaper incident was triggered by the maintenance of gas pipes in the area. [size=about 20]

On 30 November, 15-20 residents of Quva town blocked the local road in protest of power outage and natural gas supply emergency in the district. Head of the district met with protesters to resolve the issues after which protesters unblocked the traffic. [size=15-20]

On 28 November, dozens of Kushtepa village residents in Oltinkol district of Andizhan region blocked the road in protest of power blackout in the area. The power company replaced the power transmission equipment on 29 November explaining it was caused by the out of order transmission device in the village. [size=dozens]

On 27 November, dozens of car drivers blocked the M-34 road in the town of Baht in protest of the temporary closure of a gas station while they were waiting in the long car queues at the location. [size=dozens]

On 27 November, about 70 residents of Shortanbay village blocked the local road in protest of the lack of natural gas supply. They demanded the authorities to resolve the issue. Uzbekistan authorities previously supplied villagers with coal for heating but residents complained coal quality was insufficient. [size=about 70]

On 16 November, about 100 retail shop owners gathered outside the Tashkent main bazaar management office rallying against the demolition of their shops. Protesters demanded compensation and disagreed with the management's demand to vacate shops in 15 days. [size=about100]
On 15 November, 10-15 residents of Payariq district in Samarkand region protested against the demolition of their homes. [size=10-15]
Military Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Border Service

On 10 November, Uzbek border guards physically attacked a local villager during a patrol road check in the village of Hosilot of Ferghana district for disobeying the border control check. The incident comes after the reinforcement of the border security following the IS claimed armed assault on 6 November near Tajikistan-Uzbekistan border.

On 6 November, about 100 Uzbek rioters and construction workers attacked their counterparts that are Turkish nationals. It was unclear what has triggered the conflict but RFE/RL report suggested it may have been a result of pay gap difference between Turkish and Uzbek workers. [size=about 100]

On 4 November dated news report, 15-20 trader protesters resisted the demolition works by the construction crew at the Shovot town market in Khorezm region and protested against the demolition. Protesters demanded compensation for their buildings and urged the Uzbek government to intervene in their dispute. [size=15-20]
On 23 October, several members of the banned religious group Jihadchi were arrested by the police. Police indicated the members had previous felony records for similar offences.

On 23 October, a video of an attack on the South Korean investor was published which showed more than several local villagers assaulting the foreign investor over a land dispute. Some rioters demanded the investor leave the area. [size=more than several]
On 23 October, around 100 taxi drivers protested outside the police station demanding resignation of the police official. Official was dismissed on the Uzbek authorities directive. [size= around 100]

On 21 October, 16 residents of Tashkent city appealed to the country's president in protest against the city authorities plan to evict them from their houses against their will. Protesters insisted they will not move out until their demands are met. [size=16]
On 16 October, 5-10 local traders protested against the Mayor's plan to alter the bazaar in town in Bekabad. Protesters demanded halt to any changes at the local market. [size=5-10]

On 16 October, more than 100 members and supporters of Adolat party rallied against high cost of prescription and unregulated sale of drugs in the country's pharmacies in Tashkent. Adolat party called for more oversight of the pharmacy industry in Uzbekistan. [size=more than 100]

On 16 October, members of Hizb ut-Tahrir were arrested in Andijan region [coded to Andijan] over engaging in propaganda of religious 'extremism'. Uzbek police didn't provide the number of arrested members.

On 16 October, members of Hizb ut-Tahrir were arrested in Namangan region [coded to Namangan] over engaging in propaganda of religious 'extremism'. Uzbek police didn't provide the number of arrested members.

On 16 October, members of Hizb ut-Tahrir were arrested in Fergana region [coded to Fergana] over engaging in propaganda of religious 'extremism'. Uzbek police didn't provide the number of arrested members.

On 15 October, a dozen of local neighborhood residents protested against the councilman's plan to build a separate road in Bektemir. Residents demanded the road built according to the needs of the residents. [size=a dozen]

On 12 October, 6 protesters recorded a video urging authorities to intervene in their case in Urgut. They asked their salaries to be paid and to investigate assault on them in Jizzakh province. Protesters said they had been beaten and their salaries were not paid to them for a construction job. [size=6]

On 3 October, 20 demonstrators gathered outside the Health Ministry in Tashkent demanding to stop banning prescription of drugs. They urged the health officials to pay attention to their health rights and access to drugs necessary for their condition. [size=20]

On 3 October, a group of villagers attempted to lynch suspected thieves in Beshkapa after catching and beating them in the process of committing an alleged crime. Police took the suspects in custody. [size=no report]

Around 2 October 2019, several dozen policemen protested at the police academy in Bektemir district of Tashkent city against forced labor upon learning that they are going to be sent to pick cotton in cotton fields. [size=several dozen]

On 22 September, a journalist based in the Khorezm region and over 20 of his relatives and associates went by foot to Tashkent, demonstratively protesting against alleged harassment by law enforcers. But already the next day the protesters were detained in their way through the Urgench district of the region by law enforcers for an unsanctioned protest. [size=over 20]

Since 22 September, law enforcers in Namangan have been reportedly forcing visitors and traders of the local market to shave their beards. They complain about the fact, since they believe that shaving beards violates the rules of Islam. The authorities refused to comment.

On 19 September, protesters affiliated to the Ecological Movement of Uzbekistan gathered in Tashkent for a picket protests against allegedly illegal cutting trees in the city. The exact number of protesters was not reported. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Prison Guards

On 19 September, a resident of the Besharyk district of Ferghana region died. Reportedly he had been earlier detained for a minor crime and arrested for 10 days, but then policemen returned him in a very grave condition; he passed away several hours later. An investigation revealed a fracture of his neck and sources from the court confirmed that the man was beaten by law enforcers in the jail.

On 16 September, dozens of residents of the Baliqchi district in Uzbekistan gathered near the building of the local administration. They complained about the fact that the last year the authorities had demolished their houses but had not yet given them proper compensation or another housing. They also declared hunger strike and aim to stay right in front of the administrative building until their demands are fulfilled. [size=dozens]

On 12 September, a young resident of Tashkent was brutally murdered by two assailants, shortly after he had revealed his homosexual orientation online. The investigator confirmed that the attack was most likely related to this fact.
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Prison Guards
Prisoners (Tajikistan); IRPT: Islamic Renaissance Party of Tajikistan

On 7 September, the IRPT party issued a statement on alleged torture of its former official recognized as a political prisoner by the UN. His wife claims that he is tortured physically as well as mentally to denounce IRPT and the pressure is increasing. According to her, he was also beaten and refused necessary medication. The location of his detention was not specified [coded to Tashkent].

Property destruction: Around 6 September 2019, authorities in the Akaltyn district, Uzbekistan, destroyed a number of private properties belonging to the local entrepreneurs in Sardoba township, without notifying them in advance or providing compensation. Furthermore, the owners claim that the authorities threatened them not to make public complaints, otherwise there would be criminal cases opened against them.

On 5 September, about 10-12 activists, including journalists, gathered in Tashkent near the embassy of the US, protesting against a criminal case being held against a prominent Uzbek journalist which not allowed her to leave the country. [size=about 10-12]

On 2 September, the President of Uzbekistan signed a special law on protecting women from harassment and violence, including psychological, physical and sexual attacks, and condemning their oppression in the society. [coded to Tashkent]

On 31 August, about a dozen of activists based in Tashkent were summoned to police stations, where law enforcers warned them not to hold a gathering in the upcoming day on the Independence Day of Uzbekistan. Reportedly, activists refused and insisted on holding the event. No detentions were reported.

Since 23 August, law enforcers in Tashkent have been reportedly detaining dozens of male residents and forcing them to shave their beards; according to the targeted males, for religious reasons. However, the officials denied such interpretations and claimed that only a limited action was launched against individuals with covered faces and no forced shaving happened. [coded according to the version of the civilians]

On 15 August, about 100 coal mine workers rallied outside the coal project management office in Sariasiya district urging Uzbek authorities to intervene in their conflict with the state company management. The Special Commission members met with the protesters to address the conflict. [size=about 100]

On 15 August, police forces of the Yangibozor district reportedly attacked and tortured a local resident in order to obtain a confession to an alleged theft. The victim was later transferred to a hospital.

On 14 August, about 200 coal mine workers protesters rallied outside the coal project office in Sariasiya district demanding wage increase. Protesters urged Uzbek authorities to investigate embezzlement of state funds at the project. [size=about 200]
On 14 August, a group of men lynched three young men in Oqtosh district, who reportedly had threatened a local girl with a knife. Later they also robbed them of cell phones and cash. [size=a group]

On 14 August, about 200 workers of a local mining company in the Sariosiyo district gathered to protest against allegedly terrible working conditions and illegal activities committed by the management of the company, e.g. misusing of state property. [size=about 200]

On 13 August, disgruntled women-merchants gathered at a market in the Akkurdan district, demonstrating against a newly-erected building in the area of the market and trying to demolish it. When law enforcers arrived, clashes among them and women emerged, some were detained. The exact number of individuals involved was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 9 August, around three hundred of residents of Namangan gathered to protest against reduction of size of a local cemetery and against construction of an administrative building on the spot. Reportedly, protesters aimed to remove foundations of the construction, but law enforcers prevented them doing so; no physical fight or detentions were reported. Later the protesters dispersed. [size=around three hundred]
Around 7 August 2019, victims of an alleged miscarriage of justice protested outside the country's Supreme Court in Tashkent city demanding retrial of their court cases. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) National Security Service

On 3 August, a resident of the Boysun district was reportedly attacked and beaten by the law enforcers from the local National Security Service and the police unit. The victim had to be hospitalized. [coded according to the version of the civilian]

On 2 August, the President of Uzbekistan ordered to close a prison in Zhaslyk in Karakalpakstan. The facility was significantly infamous in the country for frequent torture and as a prison for regime opponents and those convicted for 'religious radicalism'. The decision was widely reflected domestically as well as abroad.

On 1 August, two single mothers came on a square in Nukus with their children and posters stating that they were protesting against poverty and declaring a hunger strike. Two other men were with them and were filming them. All six individuals were later severely beaten (men could hardly walk after) [coded to the version of the civilians] and detained by law enforcers in front of the children. Reportedly, policemen attacked also a group of bystanders, including foreigners, by chance and taking photos of the protest. [size=around 6]'.

On 31 July 2019, drivers and bystanders protested against police officers wanted to detain a local driver who was resisting arrest in Margilan city business district. Protesters demanded policemen refrain from using excessive force while apprehending a driver. [size=no report]

On 29 July 2019, parents of students gathered outside the state registration office in Almazar district of Tashkent city demanding the city authorities address the issue of non-restricted access to the district school for their children, which parents complained is discriminatory based on tuition for non-city residents. [size=no report]

On 26 July, hundreds (thousands, according to some reports) of protesters reportedly blocked a road in Urgench, complaining proper compensation for their demolished homes. Law enforcers reportedly tried to detain several individuals, but the crowd prevented them to do so and defended the targeted protesters. Later they dispersed. [size=hundreds]

On 26 July 2019, resettled residents of Urgench city protested near the village of Chondirqiyot in Urgench district demanding immediate compensation for their demolished properties, which protesters complained they have yet to receive. Simultaneously, protesters blocked the Urgench-Honqa motor road calling for the Urgench city Mayor to get involved in the dispute. [size=no report]

On 20 July, a resident of Yakkabag village of Kashkadarya region attacked a representative of a local administration - poured gasoline on him and set fire. The reason was his alleged corruption and an attempt to demolish his building and happened after a verbal skirmish among these two and several other residents. The representative was hospitalized.

On 14 July, law enforcers of Kasby district decided to 'punish' farmers for alleged usage of too large amount of water by locking them for hours in overheated bus during the hot summer day, some of them handcuffed. The police department refused to comment the incident. [coded according to the version of the civilians]

On 10 July 2019, private homeowners protested near their homes against the construction project on Astronomia street in Yunusabad district of Tashkent city, demanding the city authorities protect their property rights and halt the project. [size=no report]
Military Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Border Service

On 5 July, a skirmish occurred between border guards of Uzbekistan in the Kumkurgan district and civilians in four vehicles. Civilians insisted that they had permission to approach the border strip; guards refused and even fired some warning shots in the air to forcibly stop vehicles in motion. No injuries were reported.

On 2 July, several hundred of unemployed drivers protested in Termez against the proposed ban on the use of their vehicles for the carriage of passengers in the city. Later, the ban was removed and the administration decided to purchase new vehicles. [size=several hundred]

As reported on 2 July, an angry crowd consisting of market workers lynched two alleged thieves at a public market in Tashkent. An investigation was later opened to investigate the beating and several perpetrators were detained. [size=no report]
On 29 June, residents of Sherobod district attacked and injured an employee of the governmental compulsory enforcement bureau, who had come to their house because of their debts. [size=no report]

On 9 June, a female cleaner at a hospital in Andijan was detained over alleged theft of a phone. According to the statement, she was taken to a police station, beaten there and forced to drink vodka in order to provide confession. The phone was later found, not stolen. Law enforcers denied such accusation and claim that the woman attacked the policemen but refused to comment publicly. [coded according to the civilian version]
Labour Group (Uzbekistan); Police Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-)

On 5 June, authorities of the Toyloq district ordered to demolish an allegedly illegally erected building, but family members of its owner and other individuals attacked the demolition crew with stones. Law enforcers arrived and detained some of them, reportedly predominantly women, to calm the situation. Later they claimed that they did not pay attention to the gender of the individuals. [size=no report]

On 5 June, an angry crowd gathered in Toshloq village, Tashkent region, following detention of an alleged pedophile, calling the police to give him for a lynch. Policemen resisted and protected the detainee and launched further investigation of alleged attempt to attack an 8 y.o. girl. [size=no report]

On 2 June 2019, dozens of taxi-minivan drivers protested in Termez city against the city ban on livery minivan operators to carry passengers in their vehicles because of safety concerns and improper registration. [size=dozens]

On 29 May 2019, workers of the state-owned alcohol manufacturing plant protested outside the factory in Kokand city against mass lay off demanding the plant management provide official reasons for unemployment of about 100 workers. [size=no report]

On 21 May, four women were detained by law enforcers of the National Guard, trying to enter a reception of the chair of the Women's Committee of Uzbekistan in Tashkent, where they intended to organize an appeal. Later they were sentenced to 10 days of administrative arrest. [size=4]

On 20 May 2019, residents of the apartment building on Amir Temur street in Yunusabad district of Tashkent city protested outside their homes against the construction of the multi-storey housing project in their backyard, demanding the authorities address safety concerns. [size=no report]

On 13 May, a picket protest took place in Tashkent. Protesters from the Human Rights Alliance of Uzbekistan gathered commemorating the so-called Andijan events (2005) and demanded their proper investigation. According to the photos, around a dozen individuals participated. [size=around a dozen]
Labour Group (Uzbekistan); Police Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-)

On 10 May, residents of Izbaskan, Andijan region were throwing stones at workers and bulldozers, sent to demolish their homes. Law enforcers arrested the attackers. The reasons for the demolition were not revealed. [size=no report]

On 10 May, four activists gathered in Tashkent, demanding investigation of several judges, who, reportedly, repeatedly issued unlawful verdicts. The event lasted for around 30 minutes, until a representative of the court invited them for a talk. [size=4]

On 4 May, a resident of Andijan was detained by law enforcers, interrogated and reportedly tortured, forcing to provide false confession. According to his relatives, being again summoned to the police station for the following day, but fearing of being tortured again, he rather committed suicide on May 5. His body was found several days later [coded according to the civilian's version].
Police Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) National Security Service

On 17 April, National Security Service police officials tortured a prisoner over six hours at the Qorovulbozor Labor Camp, Bukhara region. He was reportedly 'beaten and put under psychological pressure' to sign false statements and testify against an innocent person.

On 14 April, unknown individuals attacked a resident of Samarkand region, because of his homosexual orientation. They were reportedly beating him severely, threatened to kill him and also filmed the whole attack. He also said that he is afraid to contact law enforcers and fears about loss of respect in his district.

On 10 April, protesters gathered in Tashkent, protesting against hikes of mortgage rates. They say that they were given apartments by the President, but now the fees were risen unexpectedly and significantly. The mayor of Tashkent met with the protesters and promised a solution. [size=no report]

On 9 April, about 60 residents of Tashkent gathered in the city center, protesting against rising prices of housing. According to them, they were 'tricked' by police and (non-violently) taken away by buses. [size=about 60]
On 9 April, law enforcers in Tashkent attacked an elderly man in a street; according to him, they perhaps confused him with a homeless, because he was on his way from work wearing dirty clothes.

On 5 April, protesters gathered in Tashkent, protesting against hikes of mortgage rates. They say that they were given apartments by the President, but now the fees were risen unexpectedly and significantly. [size=no report]

On 26 March, two civilians in Khiva were reportedly attacked and beaten by a policeman for asking to behave more politely. Later both were transferred to local police station, where law enforcers wanted to seize their phone and delete video of an attack that was filmed by them; the owner denied to unlock the phone and later were both released.

On 5 March 2019, an elderly disabled resident of Kasansky district in Kashkadarya region [coded to Kasan with GP2] was reportedly detained and beaten by law enforcers and the traffic police. Then he had to be transferred to a hospital. Reason unknown.

On 27 February, a resident of Altynsay district was attacked and injured by law enforcers, when he tried to protect his father against them. He and his father and brother were later reportedly violently arrested and transferred to local police station, but on their way he had to be taken to a hospital first [coded to Qarluq].
Police Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) National Security Service

On February 11th, a former head of the State security service (left the position only three days before) and another high official of Uzbekistan were arrested in Tashkent. The official reason of his detention was declared a health issue, but several sources emphasized that the arrest is related to numerous other recent high-ranking arrests in the security apparatus and rather is a result of power struggle.

On 23 January, about 100 representatives of the staff of the bakery factory 'Asaka don Mahsulotlari' suspended their work and gathered outside the office of management near the city of Shakhrixan, demanding the payment of wage arrears and its increase. [size=about 100]

On 9 January, a handful of women gathered near the Senate building in Tashkent, demanding to meet with the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan. The women came to the capital from Khorezm, Samarkand with a complaint of illegal actions perpetrated by local officials. Shortly after start of the protest, the women were detained by the police, an administrative penalty was imposed on them. [size=a handful]

On 14 December 2018, residents of private homes on Amir Temur street in Tashkent city protested against the construction activity in the neighborhood, demanding to stop the fencing works around their houses. [size=no report]

On 12 December 2018, residents of the residential apartment building on Babur street in Yakkasaray district of Tashkent city protested outside their properties against illegal demolition activity by the construction company demanding to stop the demolition works. [size=no report]

On 10 December, the former representative of Uzbekistan to the OSCE was arrested in Tashkent and charged with high treason. According to HRW and local activists, he was under pressure and tortured in detention, in order to obtain his confession.

On 7 December, a resident of Tashkent was reportedly beaten by law enforcers in order to provide his confession of a robbery in the house of a local official. Later he was transferred to a hospital for treatment.

On 27 November, law enforcers of the traffic police reportedly attacked a driver, resident of the village of Gurumsaray, Popsky district of Namangan region, and beat him to death. Reportedly he did not follow their order to stop his vehicle. He was transferred to the hospital but died.
On 24 November, more than 300 workers of Shortanneftgas gathered in Karshi to protest against their dismissal. [size=more than 300]
On 6 November 2018, police forces detained more than 30 farmers in the district of Yazyavan on the order of the local Khokim for failing to deliver the required amount of cotton.
On 5 November, 324 employees of Shortanneftegaz protested in Guzar against the decision of the company to dismiss them. [size=324]
Protestant Christian Group (Uzbekistan); Korean Ethnic Group (Uzbekistan)

On 30 September, police detained and questioned around 40 ethnic Korean protestant Christians for 12 hours for attending a Sunday service in Kyzl-Su, Tashkent region, resulting in the hospitalization of two of them as a result of 'psychological pressure'. Equipment, religious literature and other items were confiscated and they later received large fines.

On 27 September, a protest was held at the cement plant of Kuvasaycement, located in the city of Kuvasay in the Fergana region. The employees were protesting against mass layoffs and dismissive attitude of the management. [size=no report]

On 30 August 2018, a group of Uzbek human rights activists staged a protest outside the Prosecutor-General's Office in Tashkent. The participants demanded that a pharmacist and a convicted businessman were released . Police officers and one prosecutor using force took away the protesters' posters and attacked female participants. Then they said that the rally was not authorized. All the women were driven into a police bus and brought to police department. [size=a group]

On 29 August, a group of Uzbek human rights activists staged a protest outside the Supreme Court in Tashkent. The participants demanded that a pharmacist and a convicted businessman were released. One of the protesters, the 66-year-old rights defender was detained and fined 'for violating public order'. [size=a group]

On 28 August 2018, a group of Uzbek human rights activists staged a protest outside the Presidential residence and Prosecutor General's Office in Tashkent. They demanded to free a businessman accused of spreading drugs and tortured at the Tashkent city police directorate, a 70-year-old man 'who had been detained on fraud charges and whose property had been arrested illegally, and a 55-year-old pharmacist and inventor of a number of drugs, who is behind bars on fabricated charges. The protesters demanded to see President complain about 'lawlessness by officials', but were met by his advisors and lawyers. [size=no report]

On 23 July, 30 Uzbek women gathered in front of the Presidential office in Tashkent to meet with the President and tell him about problems they and their families have encountered with police and prosecutors. After they tried to approach him, all of the protesters were detained by the police and taken to the police department. Six of the women were later convicted of minor hooliganism and sentenced to 15 days in jail. The others were released after about six hours in the Yakka Saroy district police department. [size=30]
On 3 July, law enforcement officers detained two women, suspecting them of theft in Kattarkurgan. They forced the detained women to strip and captured the scene on video.
On 26 May, 'anti-terror' police officers 'harshly' interrogated and prosecuted a female Jehovah's Witness in Jizzakh after confiscating a phone with religious materials on it.
Police Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Prison Guards

On 10 May, an inmate of a penal colony in Navoi was subjected to a systematic torture for religious reasons. Officers allegedly attacked him, broke his teeth and jaw. It was reported by his wife on May 23 and later confirmed by another source.
Military Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Border Service
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

On April 30, agreement on international cross-border cooperation of border guards of Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan was announced by Uzbek authorities. The new mechanism of co-organization shall prevent further clashes and civil fatalities alongside the borderline, as well as increase protection of the border against illegal penetration.

Around 28 April 2018, about 50 local traders protested at the Guzar district administration's office in the town of Guzar of Kashkadarya region against the demolition of the market demanding the authorities address their grievances regarding the loss of jobs and income as a result. [size=about 50]

On 10 April, a mass brawl occurred among inhabitants of the border area around Sokh District of Uzbekistan's Fergana Region with Kyrgyzstan. The residents clashed over local water pumping station. The exact numbers of individuals involved was not reported, but at least two of them were injured and hospitalized. [size=no report]

On 9 April 2018, about 4 villagers of Sokh exclave in Uzbekistan hurled rocks at 3 Kyrgyz villagers near the Uzbek village of Sharkabod on the border with Kyrgyz region of Batken which resulted in the hospitalization of 1 Kyrgyz national after sustaining concussion injury. The attack followed a water dispute at the local water canal that is used by the Kyrgyz and Uzbek villages on the border. [size=about 4]
Military Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Border Service

On 7 April, the border guards of Uzbekistan shot a citizen of Kyrgyzstan - a resident of the Kurulush village, Jalal-Abad region. Allegedly he was on the territory of Kyrgyzstan at the moment of incident (near the village of Mamay). Later he died in a hospital. The incident raised tensions and resulted in mutual agreement of both governments to avoid violence against civilians in such cases in the future.

On 5 April, local merchants of the Guzar district, Kashkadarya region organized a protest after their marketplaces were demolished and they were driven out onto the street. Law enforcers seized mobile phones from people who took photos of the protest. The exact number of protesters is not known. [size=no report]

Since March 20th, more than 25 individuals have been arrested in Tashkent and across the country during a large police raid in a case related to the former prosecutor general and several other high-ranked officials. All are charged mostly with corruption and other financial crimes. Among other detainees is e.g. former general of the national security services. Later, 13 individuals were sentenced to various numbers of years behind bars.

On 8 March, residents of Ukchi-Almazar district of Tashkent were forcibly evicted to leave their homes and later charged with administrative offences. The city administration ordered to demolish the buildings because of a planned construction of a new business center. Direct violence by law-enforcers against the residents was reported.

On 5 March, law enforcers in Bektemir district were attacked by locals, when were trying to arrest a driver, who had violated traffic rules. Several people among his relatives and friends tried to free him from the policemen and attacked them. [size=no report]

On 5 February, doctors and medical employees of a hospital in Karshi, Kashkadarya region staged a protest in front of the buildings, which had been seized from the facility by local authorities. They claimed that the administrative seizure had been announced just a day before without a proper reason and authorities did not communicate with them regarding the case. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Prison Guards
On 3 February, relatives of a jailed journalist declared that he had been victim of a torture and ill-treatment in Tashkent since his detention on 27 September 2017.
Military Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Border Service

On 27 January, a Kyrgyz citizen was injured on the border between Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan. He had crossed the border very close to the Azhek settlement, Ala-Buka district in Kyrgyzstan/Kasansay Uzbekistan [coded to Kasansay], while looking after his sheep; after being spotted by the Uzbek border guard, he tried to escape to Kyrgyzstan, but the Uzbek forces opened fire and injured him. The shepherd was transported to an Uzbek hospital.

On 4 January, prisoners in a facility in the Kasan district of the Kashkadarya region were reportedly beaten and tortured. According to their relatives, the guards were torturing a huge group of them - beating and humiliating without any reason.
